headline: Owls Take Homecoming Game Versus Tulsa
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Behind three touchdowns from Easton Messer and three takeaways from the defense, the Florida Atlantic football team defeated Tulsa in Saturday afternoon's Homecoming game at Flagler Credit Union Stadium by a score of 40-21. The Owls (4-5, 3-3) dropped 40 points at home for the third time this season with a complete game on both sides of the ball against the Golden Hurricane (2-7, 0-6), winning the turnover margin battle 3-1. VIDEO RECAP THE BEGINNING Starting out on defense, redshirt senior DB Terez Reid picked off a pass on the fourth play of the game, the Owls' first interception of the year. FAU's first drive on offense culminated in a 39-yard field goal by Garrison Smith, extending its program record to six consecutive games with a score on the opening possession. After a goal-line stand on defense, redshirt junior QB Caden Veltkamp continued his growing connection with redshirt junior WR Jayshon Platt, hitting him down the sideline where Platt took it 47 yards for a touchdown and a 10-0 lead. THE TURNING POINT Following two Tulsa field goals early in the second, Veltkamp found a wide-open Messer for a 44-yard score to up the score to 17-6, the first of 21 unanswered points to close the half. It was then redshirt senior DB Damarius McGhee's turn to make a game-changing play, scooping up a fumble at the goal line and returning it 95 yards for the score. With the defense back on the field, senior DB Chris Keys Jr. made an interception to give it right back to the Owls, setting up the second score to Messer on an 11-yard strike to send FAU to the locker room up 31-6. THE FINISH After a quiet third quarter, a drive commanded by graduate QB Zach Gibson gave the Owls 40. A 30-yard grab from Platt on 4th-and-one flea flicker set up Messer's nine-yard score, his third of the day. Two sacks ‚Äì one by junior DE Deshaun Batiste and the other by freshman DE Josh Roberts ‚Äì kept Tulsa out of the end zone the rest of the way. OFFENSE Messer's hat trick was the first multi-score game of his collegiate career. He becomes just the sixth receiver in program history to haul in three touchdown catches in a single game. For the second week in a row, Platt recorded a 100+ yard receiving game with 114 on five catches. Sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton logged the first 100+ yard game of his career, with 107 yards on just 11 carries. He ripped off a 50-yard run, the longest of his career, to end the first quarter. DEFENSE McGhee's 95-yard fumble return is the second longest in program history, yardage not seen since the second game in the 2001 inaugural season. Leading the way in tackles was redshirt junior Leon Hart Jr. with 12. Redshirt junior LB Tyler Stolsky recorded 11 tackles, his fourth straight game in double digits. In addition to the three takeaways, the Owls' defensive unit forced three turnovers-on-downs, and recorded five sacks, eight tackles for loss and six pass breakups POSTGAME AUDIO Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley Redshirt Junior QB Caden Veltkamp Graduate QB Zach Gibson Redshirt Junior WR Easton Messer Redshirt Junior WR Jayshon Platt Graduate OL Alex Atcavage Redshirt Senior DB Terez Reid Redshirt Senior DB Damarius McGhee PHOTO GALLERY Gallery: (11-8-2025) Tulsa at Florida Atlantic UP NEXT The Owls will travel for their final road game of the 2025 season, heading to New Orleans for a matchup with Tulane on Saturday, Nov. 15. Kickoff is at 4 p.m. ET on ESPN+. FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

headline: Owls End the Night with Victory Over Charleston in Field of 68
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's men's basketball team opened up the Field of 68 Tip-Off with a wire-to-wire 94-77 victory over Charleston on Saturday evening at Liberty Arena. The Owls (2-0) jumped out to a double-digit lead over the Cougars (1-2) early and did not look back the rest of the way. In a typical balanced offensive showing under Head Coach John Jakus, six players scored in double figures, with all 13 who stepped onto the court recording points. FIRST HALF Like the previous game, redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool opened scoring. Five straight points from redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams gave the Owls an early 12-3 lead, with a dunk from junior center Vincent Neugebauer putting the team ahead by double digits. The lead grew to as big as 19, with a late shot from junior guard Kanaan Carlyle sending the Owls to the locker room with a 48-32 advantage. Defensively, Florida Atlantic did not surrender a field goal to four Charleston starters, holding them to a combined 0-for-11 shooting. SECOND HALF Two triples from junior forward Xander Pintelon put Florida Atlantic up by 20 five minutes in the second half. The Owls then worked their way in the paint, with sophomore Maxim Logue connecting on four shots in a four-minute span. Florida Atlantic led by as much as 25 and reached the 90-point mark with a three-pointer from redshirt freshman Liam Dayco-Green in his collegiate debut. PRESS CONFERENCES STATS & NOTES The Owls made the most of their second chance opportunities, outscoring the Cougars 24-7. Florida Atlantic converted 11 shots behind the arc, their second straight game with 10+ to open the season. Carlyle led the team in scoring for the second game in a row, this time with 14. Logue shot a perfect six-for-six from the field. Vanterpool had another balanced statline, logging six rebounds and five assists. Three Owls recorded the first points of their collegiate careers: Neugebauer, redshirt freshman guards Amar Amkou, and Dayco-Green FAU holds a 4-1 record in the Field of 68 Tip-Off. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will close the Field of 68 Tip-Off, facing host team Liberty on Sunday, Nov. 9. Tipoff is at 6 p.m. on the Field of 68's YouTube channel. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Jackson‚Äôs Buzzer-Beater Seals Road Win at Kennesaw State
content: KENNESAW, Ga. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team moves to 2-0 on the season, notching Coach Freeland's first road win at Florida Atlantic with a 69-68 victory over Kennesaw State on Saturday at VyStar Arena. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls trailed for much of the first quarter before Michiyah Simmons tied it at 10 with 4:33 left to go in the first. The game began to pick up speed, going back and forth, ending the first quarter with Florida Atlantic leading 19-16 off a Destyne Jackson 3-pointer. FAU started the second quarter strong, extending their lead to 26-19 in the first two minutes. Kennesaw State cut the Florida Atlantic lead to three at 29-26 by the media timeout. Jackson put the Owls' lead back to six with 30 seconds remaining in the half. The Owls entered halftime with a 37-31 lead. To start the third quarter, Kennesaw State committed three team fouls, and the Owls' lead extended to 10, 41-31, within the first minute of play. KSU began to close the lead before a Grace Carstensen 3-pointer extended the lead back to seven. The Owls then gained their largest lead of the contest at the six-minute mark with the score standing at 51-40. FAU held its lead at nine through the end of the third, taking a 61-52 lead into the final 10 minutes of play. Kennesaw State made a run in the fourth quarter, keeping Florida Atlantic from scoring for over two minutes. The Owls' lead shrank to one point, sitting at 64-63 with 3:48 to go in the game. KSU took the lead with two minutes to go in the game before Jackson called game with a corner 3-pointer with two seconds left to capture the win, 69-68. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I thought we played really well for the first three quarters, and then the fatigue set in a little bit, but I'm extremely proud of the fight and the grit to finish the game. Destyne's shot at the end of the fourth was huge. Just really proud of our team effort and our belief that we would pull it out." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Four Florida Atlantic players finished in double figures. Jackson with 13, Simmons with 12, Jess Moors with 11, and Carstensen with 10. Vivian Onugha led the team in rebounds on the night with four. Simmons had a team-leading five assists. The Owls were 50 percent from both field goal and 3-point range on the night, matching up well to Kennesaw State's 48.1 field goal percentage and 16.7 three-point percentage. UP NEXT The Owls head to Coral Gables to face Miami on Thursday, Nov. 13, at 7 p.m. inside the Watsco Center on ACC Network Extra. FOLLOW THE OWLS For updates, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Drop Three-Setter at Rice
content: HOUSTON ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic Volleyball battled tough against conference leader Rice, but the Owls fell in three sets, 3-0 (25-20, 25-19, 26-24), on the road Sunday in Houston. The Owls fall to 17-10 overall and 8-6 in American play, while Rice moves to 17-8 on the season and 13-1 in league play. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls took the early lead 2-0, scoring back-to-back points off a kill from Anna Hartman and a Rice attacking error. Florida Atlantic maintained an advantage through a 10-9 lead after a Rice service error, however, Rice produced a 5-1 run to take its first lead of the set, 14-11. FAU scored three unanswered points off a pair of kills from Olivia Hart and Kayla Richardson, as well as a hitting error, but Rice retook the lead 15-14 at the first set media timeout. Out of the break, another Rice service error and a kill from Hart put the Owls back in front, 16-15. However, a 5-0 Rice run shifted the lead once again, 20-16, forcing a pair of timeouts from the Owls. Rice closed the set on a 5-4 run to take the opening 1-0 lead. After battling through a 9-9 stalemate to open set two, Rice scored nine unanswered points to break away to an 18-9 advantage. The Owls battled back, producing a 5-1 run to cut the deficit to five, 19-14, forcing Rice to call its first timeout of set two. However, the Owls couldn't muster another run as they traded points throughout the remainder of the set, as Rice eventually took the second set 25-19 for the two-set lead. FAU took the lead to open set three, holding an 11-9 advantage after a kill from Hartman and a block from Kierstin Bevelle and Libby Ashline. Rice retook the lead 14-12 after a 5-1 run, but FAU responded to take the lead back, eventually holding a 23-21 advantage. The Owls held set point at 24-23, but a service error and two attacking errors closed out the match as Rice took the set 26-24 to claim the three-set match. STATS & NOTES Hart and Hartman paced the Owls in the match, recording 11 and 10 kills, respectively. Emsley Venard dished out a team-high 17 assists across the three sets. Isabelle Northam led the Owls' back row, recording a team-high 12 digs. Bevelle paced the Owls' block, tallying a team-best three blocks in the match. UP NEXT The Owls return home next week, hosting South Florida on Wednesday, Nov. 12, before closing the regular season against UTSA on Friday, Nov. 14, for Senior Day. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Defeated by Flames to Split Field of 68 Tip-Off
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic men's basketball team dropped the 2025 Field of 68 Tip-Off finale to Liberty by a score of 88-68 on Sunday evening. While the Flames (3-0) handed the Owls (2-1) their first loss of the season, redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool impressed with a career high 24-point performance, shooting 10-for-15 from the field. FIRST HALF For the third game in a row, Vanterpool converted the first field goal make for the Owls for his first two of 10 points in the opening period. FAU kept the game within single digits for the first 12 minutes before surrendering a three-pointer to fall behind 31-19. Continuing to find success off offensive rebounds, Florida Atlantic outscored Liberty 13-2 on second chance points in the first half. The Owls closed a 20-point deficit with a 9-2 run before entering the locker room at halftime trailing 48-30. SECOND HALF Vanterpool continued where he left off with a three-pointer to open second-half scoring. He scored eight of the Owls' first nine points, including a three-point play. Junior guard Kanaan Carlyle attacked the hoop with all eight of his points coming in the final 20 minutes. PRESS CONFERENCE STATS & NOTES Vanterpool's 24 points doubles his previous career high of 12. Sophomore forward Maxim Logue made three out of his four field goal attempts. He finished the Field of 68 Tip-Off, shooting a combined nine-for-10 from the field. Redshirt freshman guard Amar Amkou scored a career-best eight points in six minutes of action. Florida Atlantic won the rebounding battle 34-28. The Owls outscored the Flames 11-2 on fastbreak points. UP NEXT The Owls will have a week off before returning to Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on Monday, Nov. 17, for a meeting with Coastal Georgia. Tipoff is at 7 p.m. on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Owls Advance to American Conference Championship
content: CHARLOTTE, N.C. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer (11-3-2) knocked off Tulsa (5-9-4) by a 3-0 final on Wednesday in the American Conference Semifinals. The Owls advance to Saturday's Championship, where they will face either Charlotte or FIU. Ethan Schumaker opened the scoring on Wednesday in the 37th minute. Schumaker's shot from distance took a deflection off the back of a Tulsa defender, sending the goalkeeper in the opposite direction. The Owls doubled the lead just four minutes later. Oliver Moller-Jensen's shot from the top of the penalty area ricocheted off the post and in. The Owls went into halftime up 2-0. The Owls dug in and stifled the Tulsa attack for much of the second half. The Golden Hurricane were held without a shot on target in the final 45 minutes. Inside the final 10 minutes, it was Moller-Jensen who delivered the final blow. Played in on a breakaway by Mamadou Diarra, Moller-Jensen calmly slotted home his second goal of the night to make it 3-0 and seal the Owls' place in the Championship. you know he had to get the brace üòè üì∫| https://t.co/LHbWi8zTiy#BuiltToRise x @FAUMSoccer pic.twitter.com/4KRhaDUPWL ‚Äî The American (@American_Conf) November 12, 2025 Goalkeeper Alfred Mikkelsen returned from a four-game absence to earn his sixth solo clean sheet of the season. Mikkelsen needed to make just one save. The Owls will now look to earn the second conference tournament title in program history. Saturday's Championship kicks off at 6 p.m. For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

headline: Owls Earn Midweek Sweep Over Bulls
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic volleyball team earned a gritty straight-set sweep over the South Florida Bulls, 3-0 (25-21, 25-20, 25-20), on Wednesday inside the Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls improve to 18-10 overall and 9-6 in American play, but the Bulls fall to 15-11 on the season and 11-4 in conference play. HOW IT HAPPENED South Florida led early, opening the match on a 6-3 run, but the Owls responded with a 7-1 run of their own, capped off by a Kierstin Bevelle kill and a pair of Bulls' errors to give the Owls a three-point advantage at 10-7 and force a USF timeout. The Bulls tied the score at 15 and 16, however, the Owls scored three unanswered points off a kill from Maggie Allred and back-to-back USF errors to extend their lead back to three, 19-16. The Bulls cut the Owls' lead to just two at 23-21, but a kill from Kayla Richardson and an ace from Emsley Venard closed out the opening frame as the Owls took the 25-21 win. The Owls struck first in the second, but the Bulls opened the set on a 6-4 run. The Owls answered back as back-to-back Victoria Hensley aces capped off a 6-0 run to make it 10-6 and spark a USF timeout. The Bulls cut the Owls' lead to just one at 17-16 to force an FAU timeout, but the Owls locked in, closing the second set on an 8-4 run to win the set, 25-20, and take the two-set lead. South Florida once again took a lead in the third, opening the set on a 10-6 run. However, the Owls continued to flex their muscles, scoring seven unanswered points off kills from Libby Ashline and Olivia Hart and numerous USF errors to take a three-point lead at 13-10. The Bulls tied things back up, but after a 17-17 stalemate, the Owls kept firing on all cylinders, closing the match on an 8-3 run to clinch the straight-set sweep, 25-20. STATS & NOTES Hart and Ashline led the Owls offensively. Hart posted a team-leading eight kills, while Ashline tallied seven kills on a team-high .385 hitting performance in the win. Ashline also led the Owls at the net, recording a match-high five blocks. Hensley led the team in assists, dishing out a team-leading 14. Isabelle Northam led the Owls' back row, finishing with a team-best 10 digs. The Owls capitalized on numerous Bulls' hitting errors, forcing 26 USF attack errors, and dominated at the service line, outpacing the Bulls in aces, 7-0. FAU also held an advantage in blocks, 9-8. UP NEXT The Owls close out the regular season on Friday, Nov. 14, hosting the UTSA Roadrunners for Senior Day. First serve is scheduled for 6 p.m. inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Travel to Coral Gables to Challenge Miami
content: Boca Raton, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team continues its road stretch on Thursday, Nov. 13, as the Owls head to Coral Gables for a battle with ACC foe Miami. Tipoff is scheduled for 7 p.m. inside the Watsco Center on ACCNX. MATCHUP INFO Florida Atlantic (2-0) at Miami (2-0) Date: Thursday, Nov. 13 Time: 7 p.m. ET Location: Watsco Center in Coral Gables, Fla. GAME COVERAGE TV: ACCNX Live Stats: StatBroadcast A LOOK AT THE OWLS The Florida Atlantic Owls enter Thursday's midweek matchup 2-0 after earning a pair of season-opening wins over Florida Memorial, 89-46, and Kennesaw State, 69-68. The Owls are led offensively by Vivian Onugha, Grace Carstensen, Destyne Jackson, and Michiyah Simmons. Onugha leads the Owls, averaging 15.0 points per game. Carstensen ranks second on the team, recording 14.5 points per game, while Jackson and Simmons tie for third, tallying 10.5 points apiece through two games. Simmons and Ineivi Plata are tied for a team-leading 3.5 assists per game. On the glass, the Owls are led by Haley Walker, collecting 8.0 rebounds per contest, and Onugha, who ranks second on the team with 7.5 boards per game so far this season. The Owls' steals leader is Jackson, tallying 1.5 steals per game. SCOUTING MIAMI Miami enters Wednesday's contest at 2-0 after opening the season with wins over Hofstra, 83-48, and Bethune-Cookman, 74-41. The Canes are led offensively by Ra Shaya Kyle and Ahnay Adams. Kyle boasts a team-leading 16 points per game, while Adams is also averaging double-figures with 11 points per game. Kyle also paces the team in the glass, collecting a team-high 7.5 rebounds per game. Jessica Peterson and Candace Kpetikou rank second on the team, collecting 6.5 rebounds per game, each. Gal Raviv is the Canes' assists leader, dishing out a team-high 5.5 assists per game this season. Kyle, Peterson, and Natalie Wetzel are tied for the team lead in blocks, recording two blocks apiece. SERIES HISTORY Wednesday's meeting marks the 21st all-time meeting between Florida Atlantic and Miami. The Owls will look for their first win over the Canes. Miami has won 16 contests in Coral Gables, including a 75-42 win in the last meeting between the two programs on Nov. 16, 2022. LAST TIME OUT: AT KENNESAW STATE The Owls extended their season-opening winning streak to 2-0 with a 69-68 road win at Kennesaw State on Saturday. Four Florida Atlantic players finished in double figures. Jackson with 13, Simmons with 12, Jess Moors with 11, and Carstensen with 10. Vivian Onugha led the team in rebounds on the night with four. Simmons had a team-leading five assists. The Owls were 50 percent from both field goal and 3-point range on the night, matching up well to Kennesaw State's 48.1 field goal percentage and 16.7 three-point percentage. UP NEXT Following Wednesday's contest, the Owls will head to Mobile, Alabama, to close out their three-game road trip, visiting South Alabama on Thursday, Nov. 20, for an 8 p.m. tipoff on ESPN+ at the Mitchell Center. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

headline: Owls Usher In Signing Class
content: BOCA RATON, Fla ‚Äì With National Signing Day in the books for the Florida Atlantic softball team, Head Coach Jordan Clark announced eight signees set to join the program in the fall of 2026. The Owls' incoming signing class is ranked No. 35 nationally by D1Softball, the highest ranked class of any team outside of the power conferences. Coach Clark's previous signing classes have contributed to Florida Atlantic's back-to-back American Conference regular season championships and two straight NCAA Regional appearances. QUOTABLE Head Coach Jordan Clark "This class is replacing arguably one of the best classes in program history with all of their accomplishments. We expect them to come in and be able to compete quickly. This class has every position covered, with speed, power, athleticism, and experience gained from competing at the highest level. We have watched them for many years now, and it's finally time to make it official. We are excited about them as players, but also welcoming their amazing families into ours. Paradise is a special place to be, and the future is bright with this new group of Owls!!" MEET THE CLASS (Name ‚Äì Position ‚Äì Hometown ‚Äì High School ‚Äì Club/Travel Team) Emme Aslan ‚Äì UTL ‚Äì St. Cloud, Fla. ‚Äì Harmony High School ‚Äì Top Gun National Aslan was All-Conference in each of her three years playing varsity and was All-State in both 2024 and '25, in addition to being named Offensive Player of the Year in 2024. She holds a high school career batting average of .384 and an on-base percentage of .516. "Emme was our last addition to this class, but has the ability to make a big splash with her bat. She is strong and has a high hitting IQ that will make her a great hitter at the next level." Sam Basen ‚Äì UTL ‚Äì Jupiter, Fla. ‚Äì Jupiter High School ‚Äì Rock Gold Manetta Basen is a two-time member of the All-Palm Beach County First Team and was a Player of the Year nominee by the Palm Beach Post and Sun Sentinel in 2024 and 2025. In her '25 senior campaign, she led Palm Beach County in triples with eight. "Sam is a true utility player that can play just about any position on the field. She is gritty and the ultimate team player. We have gotten to watch Sam over the years from camp, and seeing her develop into the player she is today is pretty special." Olivia Bennett ‚Äì OF ‚Äì Blackshear, Ga. ‚Äì Pierce County High School ‚Äì Impact Caymol Premier Bennett was named to the All-Region team four times. In her senior season, she batted .468 and hit 30 home runs while stealing 30 bases and holding a perfect fielding percentage. "Olivia is a true lefty/lefty outfielder with a ton of athleticism. She moves well and has the ability to change the game with one swing. My favorite memory of recruiting Olivia was watching her make a catch over the fence in Colorado. Despite an injury in the process, she held on to the ball to finish the play. She then came back to the dugout to be the loudest one cheering for her teammates." Kamryn Hackett ‚Äì OF ‚Äì Okeechobee, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Virtual ‚Äì Tampa Mustangs Hackett was selected to the All-County team for Highlands County and named offensive player of the year. She is also a scholar athlete and is a member of the National Honor Society. "Kamryn is going to be really exciting to watch over the next couple of years. She is a dynamic player that will make a big impact, an all-around player with power, speed, and true utility on the infield or outfield." Hayden Holloway ‚Äì Catcher ‚Äì Bowling Green, Ky. ‚Äì IMG Academy ‚Äì Frost Falcons Holloway has batted .352 and owns an on-base percentage of .416 in her last two years of varsity play. She totaled 25 home runs. "Hayden is the player that everyone turns their head because of her tall stature when she walks by. She has an above average arm that keeps runners from advancing on the bases. She is a good receiver and will have the ability to make pitchers feel comfortable right away when throwing to her." Ava Jacobs ‚Äì Catcher ‚Äì Thiells, N.Y. ‚Äì North Rockland High School ‚Äì Stars National Coleman Jacobs is batting .355 with a 1.212 OPS for Stars National Coleman 18U. She has been named All-Section and All-League twice. "Ava is someone that I have watched for a long time. When she is on the field, you notice her right away with her passion and energy she exudes to everyone around her. She is extremely competitive and will find ways to make a difference, whether it's behind the plate or in a big-time offensive moment." Lucy Mondok ‚Äì RHP/INF ‚Äì Tarpon Springs, Fla. ‚Äì East Lake High School ‚Äì Tampa Mustangs Mondok is a three-time Pinellas County All-Conference first team member and was named the FACA 6A District 14 Player of the Year in both 2024 and '25 as well as the Pinellas County Pitcher of the Year in 2023. She also holds the East Lake home run record. "Lucy is a two-way player who will be able to pitch and make a big impact with her bat. She has great size, and her athleticism will allow her to help us in all aspects. She has the ability to be a big addition on and off the field." Lily Schlotterbeck ‚Äì RHP ‚Äì Williamsport, MD. ‚Äì Saint James School ‚Äì Stars National Coleman Schlotterbeck was named first team Washington All-County for three years and in her junior year was Washington County's Co-Player of the Year after posting a 0.99 ERA with 187 strikeouts in 85 innings. She is the sister of Florida Atlantic's All-American two-way player Trinity Schlotterbeck. "Lily is another two-way player who will pitch and hit for us. She is a true power pitcher who will have the ability to overpower hitters with size and speed. The future is really bright for Lily, and look for her to do big things in Paradise." FOLLOW THE OWLS To follow the team on social media, visit @fausoftball, or for the most up-to-date information, go to www.fausports.com.

headline: Game Notes #10
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's football team completed a competitive Wednesday practice with the knowledge that the Owls will need to bring their best efforts to New Orleans to come away with a win against Tulane and inch closer to bowl eligibility. Offensively, the Owls are led by redshirt junior quarterback Caden Veltkamp who totals 245 completions on 372 attempts for 2,589 yards and 20 scores. He has connected with 18 receivers, but none more than redshirt junior slot receiver Easton Messer, who is No. 2 nationally with 74 receptions. Messer has four TDs on the year while redshirt sophomore WR Asaad Waseem leads the team with five TDs. The bulk of the run game is expected to be handled by sophomore Kaden Shields-Dutton and redshirt sophomore Gemari Sands. Shields-Dutton leads all rushers with four scores, while Sands leads the team with 358 yards. Defensively, redshirt junior linebacker Tyler Stolsky enters the game with 72 tackles, including two for a loss of seven yards. Fellow linebacker Leon Hart Jr. has 67 tackles and four for a loss of 15 yards. Junior Deshaun Batiste leads the team with 3.5 tackles for a loss of 48 yards and will be making a return trip to New Orleans, where he attended John F. Kennedy High School. The two teams will meet for the third time, second as American Conference members. The two first met back in Boca Raton in 2013 with the Owls coming away with a 34-17 win. The Owls then fell to a No. 24 Tulane, 24-8, also in Paradise, in 2023. To follow the games: football is scheduled to play at Tulane at 4 p.m. on Saturday, Nov. 15. The game will air on ESPN+ and also will air on Fox Sports 640 AM South Florida. CELEBRATING 25 YEARS Click HERE for 25 Years Celebration Content. COMPLETE 2025 SCHEDULE Click HERE. GROUPS OF ALL AGES To purchase group tickets, click HERE. FOLLOW THE TEAM Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through football's Twitter and Instagram accounts @FAUFootball.

headline: Coach Jakus Meets with Media on Wednesday
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's basketball Head Coach John Jakus met with the media on Wednesday to discuss two upcoming home games at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. Jakus spoke about the Owls playing in the 2025 Field of 68 Tip-Off last week in Lynchburg, Virginia. Florida Atlantic returns home to take on Coastal Georgia to kick off the week on Monday, Nov. 17. Tipoff is set for 7 p.m. on ESPN+. The Owls will then host Pacific on Thursday, Nov. 20, at 7 p.m. on ESPN+ as part of a game in the Sunshine Slam tournament. FAU then hits the road to Daytona Beach, Florida on Monday, Nov. 24 and Tuesday, Nov. 25. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Owls Complete Busy Weekend
content: Bonita Bay Results BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì With players scattered around at various locations, the Florida Atlantic men's tennis team found its competitive edges in Portugal, Athens, Georgia or Bonita, Florida last weekend. Segundo Goity Zapico, a sophomore from Argentina, completed the 25K ITF Tournament in Portugal as a quarterfinalist. The M&M duo of Mark Havlicek and Marek Pazdera represented the Owls at the NCAA Southeast Section where they were just one of two playing for a non-ACC, SEC or Big Ten member. Additionally, 12 singles matches and six doubles matches were played in Bonita Bay with Jan Kusy and Luca Miremont turning in strong weekends. Returners and Czech Republic natives Simon Myslivec, a junior, and Pazdera, a sophomore, will open play on November 24. The duo will pair together the same day in doubles action. SECTIONAL RESULTS Round of 16 Sam Landau/Facundo Yunis (Indiana) def. Marek Pazdera/Mark Havlicek (Florida Atlantic) 3-6, 6-3, 1-0 (10-7) Consolation Quarterfinals Martin Breysach/Charlelie Cosnet (Kentucky) def. Marek Pazdera/Mark Havlicek (Florida Atlantic) 7-5, 6-1 FOLLOW ALONG To follow the Owls socially, visit @faumtennis, or for the most up-to-date information, go to www.fausports.com.

headline: Leroux First to Ink for 2026
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic women's basketball Head Coach LeAnn Freeland announced the first signing of the Owls' 2026 class with freshman guard Juliette Leroux on Wednesday. "Juju was one of the first recruits our staff targeted after taking the job in April," expressed head coach LeAnn Freeland. "She's an explosive, skilled guard with good size and a high basketball IQ. Her highly competitive nature, leadership, and overall production helped South Fayette win a state title in 2025, while also contributing to her AAU program, SLAAM, competing in the Power 24 circuit. Our coaching staff and players are excited to announce Juju is an Owl!" Leroux, from Bridgeville, Pa., joins the Owls as a four-year letterwinner in volleyball and basketball from South Fayette High School. Leroux is a three-time WPIAL Champion with the Lions. As a junior, the Second Team All-State honoree helped lead the Lions to the first PIAA Class 5A State Championship in school history in 2025, earning Player of the Game honors. Leroux averaged 12.3 points per game, 4.8 rebounds per game, and 1.5 assists per game during her junior season. As a sophomore, Leroux was named Second Team All-Section. She was also a three-time All-State honoree for volleyball. Academically, Leroux was named to South Fayette's highest honor roll. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook.
